learningOutcome.title: Sourcing of materials : raw material, manufactured products, clay powders
Different clay minerals and their properties
Criteria in guaging correct proportions of constituents for clay plaster
Finished plaster quality to achieve the required standard for the particular conditions of use
Behaviour of earth in relation to water : consistency, cohesion, reversibility
Principles of stabilisation of clay plaster for interior and exterior work
Preparation and mixing of clay plaster
learningOutcome.description: · Current legislative workplace requirements · Relevant codes of practice and current standards for quality of work and materials · Tools, machinery and equipment · The order of work in planning and making plaster · Safe and healthy working practices

learningOutcome.title: Manufactured products, their use and areas of application
Main constituents of earth as a raw material
Field Identification tests for earth
Awareness of impact on indoor climate and environment
Basic properties of earth - composition and texture (grain size distribution), cohesion, plasticity, colour, absorbtion)
Principal additives (aggregates, fibre, stabilisers, pigments) their use and their effects
Estimate of quantities and calculation of mixture ratios
Composition of clay plaster
Test method for determining the mixture (constituent proportions) for different plaster layers and for different areas of application
Calculate total quantities of plaster for the finished job and totals for each constituent
Organise the building site
Calculate quantities of each constituent for the mixing process
Prepare raw materials (dry, grind, size, sieve, soften in water, store, transport)
Select, calculate and source materials
Make sample panels
Comply with current legislation, official guidance and workplace safety requirements at all times
Conduct field identification tests
Select and use appropriate tools, machinery and equipment to prepare raw materials and to mix
Select the components for different plasters ; conduct test methods and interpret the results

requirement.title: The finish coat has no cracks
The proportions to guarantee a stable plaster are correct
The base coat that may have some cracks, adheres strongly to the wall
he quantities of the different constituents have been calculated according to the recipe
The chosen recipe from the test results is:
requirement.description: · correct for the plaster layer · appropriate for the application technique · suitable for selected surface finishing technique · corresponds to the desired finished texture and colour

requirement.title: The chosen recipe is clearly written down and can be repeated
Test samples are logically ordered and have a clear key
Test sample thicknesses and dimensions are the same
The grain and fiber size are appropriate for the application technique
The consistency is appropriate for the application technique and for the function of the layer
The materials are sized and sieved for the appropriate purpose
Field tests have been performed accurately
The materials are soaked for the appropriate time
The plaster mix is homogenous
The quantity of plaster is sufficient
Each mixing cycle follows the recipe
Sample boards have an appropriate key for the sample plaster finish, are well executed and can be easily transported without damage

learningOutcome.title: Source materials, in particular find raw materials and select earth samples, and prepare them
Plan and organise the process of preparing clay plaster for usual and predictable building sites
Control the quality of the plaster
Input into the decision making process concerning the plaster choice
Explain your choice of recipes for different plaster layers and for different application techniques, from both raw materials and from manufactured products
Advise on suitable areas of application for clay plaster and the benefits for indoor climate
Supervise the mixing process

unit.title: Unit n° 2 - Application of Clay Plaster

learningOutcome.title: Surface finishes and how to create them
Technical details for finishing internal and external corners, second fix carpentry, openings and ceiling and floor joins
Finished plaster quality to achieve the required standard for the particular conditions of use
Different kinds of surfaces to be plastered
Technical details for fixing services and furniture
Properties and criteria for assessment of the background: roughness; absorption capacity; stability; homogeneity; rigidity
Structural characteristics of the plaster - thickness, function, number of layers and reinforcing mesh
Suppliers
Wind and air tightness of plasters and joins
Areas of use for clay plaster; particular considerations for areas of high humidity and for exterior clay plaster
Preparing the background and applying clay plaster:
learningOutcome.description: Current legislative workplace requirements · Relevant codes of practice and current standards for quality of work and materials · Tools, machinery and equipment · The order of work · Safe and healthy working practices

learningOutcome.title: The main methods of bonding layers
Select, calculate and source materials
Prepare all fixing points for services and furniture
Comply with current legislation, official guidance and workplace safety requirements at all times
Design and execute different surface finishes and textures
Apply all shaping preparation for joins, corners, openings
Select and use appropriate tools, machinery and equipment to prepare the background and apply different layers including the final surface finish
Carry out the background preparation
Produce straight and rounded edges, finish inter- nal and external corners, openings and joins
Apply the plaster and produce a flat surface
Protect adjoining surfaces
Apply at appropriate intervals key coat, base and finish coats and achieve the desired finished plaster quality
Organise the building site
Apply reinforcing mesh

requirement.title: The corners are straight and their degree of curvature conforms to the specifications
Pipes and conduit are properly fixed within the plaster leaving no visible trace
The joins are neat where plaster meets a different material. A straight and neat separation line is executed at junctions with flexible building elements.
The adjoining surfaces are protected
If necessary the background has been cleaned; moistened and keyed
If a background key has been applied, it has been applied correctly
The reinforcing mesh is entirely embedded in the plaster layer
The mix and thickness of the different plaster layers conform to the specifications
The drying time between the different layers is sufficient
The surface has no cracks
The surface is sound (hard, not dusty or sandy, resistant to damage) for the particular conditions of use
The layers are well bonded
The plaster adheres firmly to the background
The surface flatness is according to the specifications
The finish accords with the specifications
The surface is homogenous

learningOutcome.title: Plan and organise all the steps involved from preparation of the background through to the finish for usual and predictable building sites
Supervise and co-ordinate the plastering process from preparation through to the finish
Input into decision making process for the plaster work including choice of final finish
Advise on plaster structure, application and finish

Assess the characteristics of the background and make an appropriate choice of bonding layer and an appropriate choice of plaster structure (the mix, number of layers, thickness of layers, reinforcements)
Control the quality of the work throughout preparation, application and the finish
